title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: A little beyond Newstead, on the left, is Ravenswood House.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: In this way there are passed (1) Village of Newstead on the left, and the Eiklons on the right.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: The more picturesque road, though longer, is by the village of Newstead, across the Tweed by the Fly Bridge, two miles below Melrose, near the junction of the Leader with the Tweed.

title: Heads and tales, or, Anecdotes and stories of quadrupeds and other beasts chiefly connected with incidents in the histories of more or less distinguished men /
snippet: memorable tribute of the kind since the dog's grave, of old, at Salamis is still a conspicuous ornament of the gardens of Newstead.

title: The manuscripts of His Grace the Duke of Portland, preserved at Welbeck abbey ...
snippet: — Hearing that Brigadier Sutton has been endeavouring to procure a lease of Harloe and Lindhurst for 61 years of your Lordship, and that his demands have not been agreed to; as your estate of Kirkby joins to mine of Newstead, and Harloe and Lindhurst is but half a mile from me, I should be sorry to have that command in other hands but yours, which would be very prejudicial to me and my family.

title: The manuscripts of His Grace the Duke of Portland, preserved at Welbeck abbey ...
Memoirs, journal, and correspondence of Thomas Moore.
author: Moore, Thomas
snippet: Forgot to mention that I wrote to Hobhouse from Newstead, and being touched with a kindly spirit at the time towards everything connected with poor Byron, showed it in my letter.

title: Memoirs, journal, and correspondence of Thomas Moore.
author: Moore, Thomas
snippet: Hodgson went down with me in the gig to the place where I was to meet the coach (liis wife having put into my hands before I came away a paper, which she said I might read at my leisure), and, after a most cordial parting, I started about twelve o'clock on my way for Newstead, Wildman (who is in town) having given me leave to return there for a few more inquiries  among the old servants.

title: Memoirs, journal, and correspondence of Thomas Moore.
author: Moore, Thomas
snippet: Between three and four started in a chaise for Newstead ; very kindly received by the Wildmans.

title: Memoirs, journal, and correspondence of Thomas Moore.
author: Moore, Thomas
snippet: On my arrival at Birmingham  found a letter from Wildman, to whom I had written to know whether he was at Newstead, and disposed to receive me for a day or two.

title: Memoirs, journal, and correspondence of Thomas Moore.
author: Moore, Thomas
snippet: and pass some time at Newstead, which would be a great object to me, as from his zeal in every thing rehiting to Byron, he could be of essential service to me, having studied the history of the family, of the place, &c. But an unlucky quarrel, which has occurred between him and RanclifFe, still subsists in full vigour, and I can see that E. would be annoyed if I accepted the invitation : must come some other time.

title: Memoirs, journal, and correspondence of Thomas Moore.
author: Moore, Thomas
snippet: Much struck by the first appearance of the Abbey : would have given worlds to be alone : the ftiithfulness of the description in " Don Juan ; " the ruined arch, the Virgin and Child, the fountain, &c. &c. Col. Wildman out shooting, but was sent for; introduced to Mrs. W. and the ladies in the drawing-room ; the ceilino-, which is restored, very rich ; supposed to be Italian work : Col. Wildman arrived ; showed me all over the house ; the dining-room which Byron used when he first took possession, the small apartment he afterwards occupied, dinner, sitting, and bedroom; some furniture of his in Wildman's study brought from Cambridge ; the monument  to the dog ; his own intention was that he should be buried in a vault at Newstead, with his dog and old Murray (?); the little oak before the house planted by himself; a plantation at a distance (beyond the lake ?) also planted by himself; picture of " little Sir John Avith the great beard ; " the panels with the heads new painted and gilt by Wildman: imagines that there was some story connected Avith them, as in all of them there is the head of a female, with a Moor on one side, and sometimes a Christian on the other, gazing at her.
